content: Singaporean cabinet post overseeing government transitions **Minister Mentor** was a position in the [Cabinet of Singapore](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore) created in 2004 as part of a transition in political leadership. The first and only person to hold the post, between 2004 and 2011, was [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew). ## Background On 12 August 2004, when [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong) succeeded [Goh Chok Tong](/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong) as the [prime minister of Singapore](/wiki/Prime_minister_of_Singapore), he announced the position of Minister Mentor, as part of a transition of political leadership, when naming his [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore). Prior to Lee Kuan Yew's appointment as Minister Mentor, he was [Senior Minister](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore) between 1990 and 2004 under [Goh Chok Tong's Cabinet](/wiki/Fourth_Goh_Chok_Tong_Cabinet). Goh was subsequently appointed Senior Minister under [Lee Hsien Loong's Cabinet](/wiki/First_Lee_Hsien_Loong_Cabinet) when he stepped down as prime minister. On 14 May 2011, following the [general election](/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election) that took place seven days earlier, Lee Kuan Yew and Goh Chok Tong announced their retirement from the Cabinet, but continued to serve as [Members of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) (MPs) on the [backbenches](/wiki/Backbencher) until [Lee's death in 2015](/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Lee_Kuan_Yew) and Goh's retirement from politics in 2020 respectively.
